sentences: Fritz Busch (13 March 1890 – 14 September 1951) was a German conductor.

At the Stuttgart Opera (1918 to 1922) he modernised the repertory, and at the Dresden State Opera (1922 to 1933) he presented world premieres of operas by Richard Strauss, Ferruccio Busoni, Paul Hindemith and Kurt Weill among others.

At the Stuttgart Opera (1918 to 1922) he modernised the repertory, and at the Dresden State Opera (1922 to 1933) he presented world premieres of operas by Richard Strauss, Ferruccio Busoni, Paul Hindemith and Kurt Weill among others.
Being an ardent Anti-Nazi, Busch was dismissed from his post as director at Dresden in 1933 and made most of his later career outside Germany.

He conducted in New York and London, but his main bases were Buenos Aires, where he was in charge at the Teatro Colón for several opera seasons in the 1930s and 1940s; Copenhagen and Stockholm, conducting the Danish Radio Symphony Orchestra and the Stockholm Philharmonic; and Glyndebourne in England, where he was the founding musical director of Glyndebourne Festival Opera working together with the stage director Carl Ebert.

section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: Busch was born on 13 March 1890 in Siegen, Westphalia, the eldest of eight children of Wilhelm Busch and his wife Henriette, née Schmidt.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: It was a musical family; Wilhelm and Henriette supplemented their incomes by performing dance music at weekends.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: As a boy, Busch took music lessons with his father and others, and in 1906 he entered the Cologne Conservatory, studying harmony and counterpoint with Otto Klauwell, piano with Karl Boettcher and later Lazzaro Uzielli, and conducting with the principal, Fritz Steinbach.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: In 1909 Busch spent a season as conductor at the Deutsches Theater, Riga, and in 1911 and 1912 he toured as a pianist.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: In 1909 Busch spent a season as conductor at the Deutsches Theater, Riga, and in 1911 and 1912 he toured as a pianist.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: In 1911 Busch married Margarete Boettcher, a niece of his piano teacher; their first son, Hans, later a stage director, was born in 1914.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: In 1911 Busch married Margarete Boettcher, a niece of his piano teacher; their first son, Hans, later a stage director, was born in 1914.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: Busch remained at Aachen until the outbreak of the First World War in 1914, when he enlisted in the German army, rising from the ranks to become a junior officer.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: In 1918 Busch successfully applied for the vacant post of Württemberg Court Kapellmeister – musical director of the Stuttgart Opera – in succession to Max von Schillings.
section: == Life and career == | === Stuttgart and Dresden ===

sentences: The conservative tradition of the house, until then the court opera of the Kingdom of Württemberg within the German Empire, was swept away in the November Revolution of 1918, and Busch took advantage of the freedom to widen the repertoire, introducing new works by composers including Hindemith and Pfitzner, and presenting modern stagings such as Adolphe Appia's for Wagner's Ring.
section: == Life and career == | === Stuttgart and Dresden ===

section: == Life and career == | === Stuttgart and Dresden ===

sentences: In 1922, Busch was appointed musical director of the Dresden State Opera.
section: == Life and career == | === Stuttgart and Dresden ===

sentences: This was success indeed: a musician in his early thirties raised to the post where Ernst von Schuch himself had conducted the premieres of [Richard Strauss's] Salome, Elektra and Der Rosenkavalier.
section: == Life and career == | === Stuttgart and Dresden ===

sentences: To Dresden's series of Strauss premieres Busch added Intermezzo (1924) and Die ägyptische Helena (1928)).

sentences: In 1927, at the invitation of Walter Damrosch, he made his American debut, conducting the New York Symphony Orchestra: the climax of the programme was the nine-year-old Yehudi Menuhin's first performance of the Beethoven Violin Concerto.
section: == Life and career == | === Stuttgart and Dresden ===

sentences: In 1932 Busch was invited to conduct Mozart's Die Entführung aus dem Serail at the Salzburg Festival.
section: == Life and career == | === Stuttgart and Dresden ===

sentences: Having recently been much impressed by Carl Ebert's staging of that opera in Berlin, Busch accepted the invitation on condition that Ebert should be engaged as director.
section: == Life and career == | === Stuttgart and Dresden ===

sentences: He made no secret of his contempt for the Nazis, and after Adolf Hitler came to power in 1933, Busch was dismissed by the Nazi-dominated Saxon Landtag.
section: == Life and career == | === Stuttgart and Dresden ===

sentences: From 1933 Busch's career was mostly outside Germany.

sentences: Returning to Europe at the end of the year he began a long association with the Danish Radio Symphony Orchestra and the Stockholm Philharmonic.
section: == Life and career == | === Buenos Aires, Copenhagen, Stockholm and Glyndebourne ===

sentences: In the early 1930s an English landowner, John Christie, and his wife, the singer Audrey Mildmay, conceived the idea of staging country house opera in a purpose-built opera house on the Christie estate at Glyndebourne in Sussex.
section: == Life and career == | === Buenos Aires, Copenhagen, Stockholm and Glyndebourne ===

sentences: In November 1933 Christie sounded Busch out about becoming his musical director; Busch was by then contractually committed in Buenos Aires, but a financial crisis in Argentina shortly afterwards enabled him to reconsider Christie's invitation.
section: == Life and career == | === Buenos Aires, Copenhagen, Stockholm and Glyndebourne ===

sentences: The level achieved by the carefully chosen and rehearsed ensemble at the summer festivals, 1934–1939, is part of operatic history.

sentences: Both at the time and later two musical idiosyncrasies were commented on: Busch's use of a piano rather than a harpsichord to accompany recitatives and the avoidance of appoggiaturas – in both respects German musical practice being old-fashioned by international standards of the day.
section: == Life and career == | === Buenos Aires, Copenhagen, Stockholm and Glyndebourne ===

sentences: Busch remained musical director at Glyndebourne until the outbreak of the Second World War in 1939, when the festival was suspended.
section: == Life and career == | === Buenos Aires, Copenhagen, Stockholm and Glyndebourne ===

sentences: He made his London debut in 1938, conducting the London Symphony Orchestra at the Queen's Hall in a programme of Mozart, Beethoven and Brahms.
section: == Life and career == | === Buenos Aires, Copenhagen, Stockholm and Glyndebourne ===

sentences: Busch continued to conduct at the Teatro Colón (1934–1936 and 1940–1947).
section: == Life and career == | === Buenos Aires, Copenhagen, Stockholm and Glyndebourne ===

sentences: Until 1940 he worked in Scandinavia during the winter months.

sentences: From June 1940 to 1945 he conducted mostly in South America, except for a not wholly successful Broadway experiment on Glyndebourne lines (the New Opera Company) and guest appearances with the New York Philharmonic, both in 1942.

sentences: In 1945 he conducted at the Metropolitan Opera, making his debut there with Lohengrin, and toured with the company for four seasons.

sentences: In 1950 Busch returned to Glyndebourne when the main festival resumed there after the war.

sentences: He returned to Glyndebourne later in the year for an all-Mozart festival – Così fan tutte, Figaro and Don Giovanni, and the first professional production in England of Idomeneo.
section: == Life and career == | === Buenos Aires, Copenhagen, Stockholm and Glyndebourne ===

sentences: In the early post-war years the Glyndebourne company appeared regularly at the Edinburgh Festival, and in August 1951 Busch was in Edinburgh to conduct his first post-war Verdi opera for the company, La forza del destino.
